aspace_helpers.title: construct MARC record from C0140 ASpace component
Generating MARC records from C0140 EAD component records/archival objects in Resource records

comments.body:
@regineheberlein 

1. aspace_C0140_c74364-56855 is a digital file so wouldn't have a container. 
2. There was a data issue with aspace_C0140_c72729-43518; I've corrected it.
3. aspace_C0140_c87678-60535 does have a container associated with it (Box P-000190). 

Can the transformation be tweaked to account for components without containers?

@faithc Can you double-check on aspace_C0140_c87678-60535? It exports without a container. Also, it seems to be set to "internal", so should it be skipped regardless? ``` Francis Ray Farm Journal /repositories/5/archival_objects/1459050 Ray, Francis 1 box 1858-1890 Immediate Source of Acquisition

Purchased from Dan Casavant Rare Books in 2022 (AM-2022-112).

 Processing Information

These materials were processed and described by Phoebe Nobles in March, 2022, incorporating some description provided by the dealer.

 Scope and Contents

The partial journal kept by Francis Ray and his son Josiah T. Ray. It includes accounts of shoe sales (possibly shoes for plow animals), accounts of farm produce such as corn, tomatoes and onions, and some sales of honey, whiskey, brandy and guns, as well as accounts for day labor. The journal contains a last will and testament for Francis Ray, leaving his estate to Josiah Ray and requesting that Josiah support his mother Elizabeth Ray; the will also mentions daughters Catherine Ray and Nellie Ray. The journal comes from the Hawfields, a region in Thompson Township, Alamance County, North Carolina, where both people with West African ancestry and Ulster Irish immigrants settled. The journal likely includes records of Black customers and possibly those who were formerly enslaved (possibly including Charles Minor, Olson Stanford, and Frank Morrow). Oak Grove Plantation was nearby.

 Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements

In conservation receiving treatment; fragile condition.

 Agricultural laborers -- Southern States -- History -- 19th century. African American agricultural laborers -- Southern States -- History -- 19th century. Alamance County (N.C.) Ledgers (account books) -- 19th century ```

@faithc 

C0140_c74364-56855 has no instances--just double-checking that's as it should be, since you're calling it a digital file.

> @faithc Can you double-check on aspace_C0140_c87678-60535? It exports without a container. Also, it seems to be set to "internal", so should it be skipped regardless? > > ``` > > > Francis Ray Farm Journal > /repositories/5/archival_objects/1459050 > >Ray, Francis > 1 > box > type="inclusive">1858-1890 > > > Immediate Source of Acquisition >

Purchased from Dan Casavant Rare Books in 2022 (AM-2022-112).

> > > Processing Information >

These materials were processed and described by Phoebe Nobles in March, 2022, > incorporating some description provided by the dealer.

> > > Scope and Contents >

The partial journal kept by Francis Ray and his son Josiah T. Ray. It > includes accounts of shoe sales (possibly shoes for plow animals), accounts > of farm produce such as corn, tomatoes and onions, and some sales of honey, > whiskey, brandy and guns, as well as accounts for day labor. The journal > contains a last will and testament for Francis Ray, leaving his estate to > Josiah Ray and requesting that Josiah support his mother Elizabeth Ray; the > will also mentions daughters Catherine Ray and Nellie Ray. The journal comes > from the Hawfields, a region in Thompson Township, Alamance County, North > Carolina, where both people with West African ancestry and Ulster Irish > immigrants settled. The journal likely includes records of Black customers > and possibly those who were formerly enslaved (possibly including Charles > Minor, Olson Stanford, and Frank Morrow). Oak Grove Plantation was > nearby.

> > > Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements >

In conservation receiving treatment; fragile condition.

> > > Agricultural laborers -- Southern States -- History -- > 19th century. > African American agricultural laborers -- Southern States > -- History -- 19th century. > Alamance County (N.C.) > Ledgers (account books) -- 19th century > > > ``` Sooo, this is bizarre. The archival object record looks totally fine to me as does the top container record. And I don't even know how a record can be set to "internal." Everything is marked "Publish."
I see it--this one is different on staging!
How about C0140_c74364-56855? Is that all right?
Yeah, I confirmed with Kelly that it's a digital object that's not online, so it's fine. Thanks for checking in about it.

i1874: deploy as bibdata, not marc_liberation

comments.body:
Discussed with @acozine and @kayiwa the https://github.com/pulibrary/princeton_ansible/pull/2781. @acozine will  update the pr to ensure that it renames the directory and not deletes it. 
We will test the updated https://github.com/pulibrary/princeton_ansible/pull/2781 pr on bibdata-staging. 
We want to make sure that files in directory with name `marc_liberation_files` will not be deleted when we change it to `bibdata`: 
data/marc_liberation_files -> /data/bibdata_files , 
/data/marc_liberation_files/scsb_update_files -> /data/bibdata_files/scsb_update_files,
/data/marc_liberation_files/figgy_ark_cache -> /data/bibdata_files/figgy_ark_cache,
/data/marc_liberation_files/partner_update_scratch -> /data/bibdata_files/partner_update_scratch

To test:

- [x] Run the updated playbook. @acozine will let us know when it's ready to test. we tested on staging.
- [x] Deploy this bibdata branch to bibdata-staging
- [x] Trigger an incremental publishing job in the Alma sandbox. it indexed the files
- [x] Import a daily update from scsb. It indexed the files
- [x] Trigger a General publishing job in the alma sandbox. triggered on 08/12/22
- [x] Make sure the files will transfer in the right directories in bibdata-staging
- [x] Make sure the incremental files will be indexed.
- [x] triggered a request for full files from HL
- [ ] trigger an import of the full pertner files
- [ ] Make sure you can run a full reindex. We started the PUL full reindex around 10:15am 08/12/22.
- [ ] In order to run the playbook on bibdata production make sure that will happen not in hours that we get incremental files from Alma. The files are initializing in Alma at 4am, 10am, 4pm, 10pm and are in bibdata in the next 60 mins. during maintenance window. Take one machine at aa time.

Re: spotlight decisions, I believe spotlight will have to make their javascript packages available via npm in order to participate in the current ecosystem. dpul.title: Load time for home page of Sid Lapidus DPUL Exhibit is Super Slow.

comments.body: We ran the solr query locally on the solr box, and were finding run times of around 3 seconds. We're now not sure if that's the problem exactly, so we're going to get datadog running again and check the performance via APM.
In APM we saw that this home page is hitting solr twice. Presumably once for the facets and once for the embedded browse content.

orangelight.title: Sitemap creator gives error when run locally

comments.body:
[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/51630699/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/51630699)

Coverage remained the same at 94.506% when pulling **1a717467f5cee4ac15a0f282f4209f8f7be5bf1a on 3104-doc** into **201c272894c1582c432d7eb0fc19e99373db1b29 on main**.

When I checked catalog2 today, there were no sitemap files at all in the public directory.

It looked like the previous run had failed after creating sitemap377.xml.gz with:

```
RSolr::Error::ConnectionRefused: Connection refused - {:params=>{:wt=>:json, "q"=>"*:*", "fl"=>"id", "cursorMark"=>"AoEsU0NTQi03MDM5NzYy", "rows"=>1000, "sort"=>"id asc"},
 :method=>:get, :query=>"wt=json&q=*%3A*&fl=id&cursorMark=AoEsU0NTQi03MDM5NzYy&rows=1000&sort=id+asc", :path=>"select", :uri=>#<URI::HTTP http://lib-solr8-prod.princeton.e
du:8983/solr/catalog-alma-production/select?wt=json&q=*%3A*&fl=id&cursorMark=AoEsU0NTQi03MDM5NzYy&rows=1000&sort=id+asc>}
/opt/orangelight/shared/bundle/ruby/2.7.0/gems/rsolr-2.5.0/lib/rsolr/client.rb:218:in `rescue in execute'
/opt/orangelight/shared/bundle/ruby/2.7.0/gems/rsolr-2.5.0/lib/rsolr/client.rb:208:in `execute'
/opt/orangelight/shared/bundle/ruby/2.7.0/gems/rsolr-2.5.0/lib/rsolr/client.rb:203:in `send_and_receive'
(eval):2:in `get'
/opt/orangelight/releases/20220801163717/config/sitemap.rb:16:in `block (2 levels) in run'
/opt/orangelight/releases/20220801163717/config/sitemap.rb:15:in `loop'
/opt/orangelight/releases/20220801163717/config/sitemap.rb:15:in `block in run'
/opt/orangelight/shared/bundle/ruby/2.7.0/gems/sitemap_generator-6.2.1/lib/sitemap_generator/interpreter.rb:61:in `instance_eval'
/opt/orangelight/shared/bundle/ruby/2.7.0/gems/sitemap_generator-6.2.1/lib/sitemap_generator/interpreter.rb:61:in `eval'
/opt/orangelight/shared/bundle/ruby/2.7.0/gems/sitemap_generator-6.2.1/lib/sitemap_generator/link_set.rb:40:in `create'
/opt/orangelight/shared/bundle/ruby/2.7.0/gems/sitemap_generator-6.2.1/lib/sitemap_generator.rb:42:in `method_missing'
/opt/orangelight/releases/20220801163717/config/sitemap.rb:6:in `run'
/opt/orangelight/shared/bundle/ruby/2.7.0/gems/sitemap_generator-6.2.1/lib/sitemap_generator/interpreter.rb:78:in `instance_eval'
/opt/orangelight/shared/bundle/ruby/2.7.0/gems/sitemap_generator-6.2.1/lib/sitemap_generator/interpreter.rb:78:in `run'
/opt/orangelight/shared/bundle/ruby/2.7.0/gems/sitemap_generator-6.2.1/lib/sitemap_generator/tasks.rb:51:in `block (2 levels) in <top (required)>'
/opt/orangelight/shared/bundle/ruby/2.7.0/gems/rake-12.3.3/exe/rake:27:in `<top (required)>'

Caused by:
Faraday::ConnectionFailed: end of file reached
```

There were successful runs in the logs, so I was surprised not to see any residual files from previous runs nor the first 377 files from this run.

I want to check to see if the sitemap files remain after a deployment.

Also a note that running this on prod takes something like 30 hours.  So it's definitely possible for some kind of minor solr connection blip to happen during that time, so we should also investigate making this more resilient against solr blips.

pdc_describe.title: DataCite - Using an existing ARK updates the ezid metadata

comments.body: @bess It was not clear, but there was already ARK validation in the system: https://github.com/pulibrary/pdc_describe/pull/281/files#diff-ebe838f9d71d26b6227d6d37c96a7e2d93fb68a80d55075c7f2374bfcb4688abR339-R343

pdc_describe.title: Error screen when attempting to edit a dataset
Describe and migrate this record: Sowing the Seeds for More Usable Web Archives

comments.body:
@Bess (@kelynch fyi ) I think we are going to need to talk further about how the metadata in Dublin Core will be translated to Datacite. There are cases where this may not move neatly. 

For example, Neggin shared this record with me: [Supplement to PhD Dissertation: "Subsurface Computational Modeling and Policy Analysis of Large-Scale Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage (2022)"](https://dataspace.princeton.edu/handle/88435/dsp01n870zt98h)

"Referenced By" in Neggin's example and "Related Publication" in Bess's example (if an ID is available for the publication) may both fall under the "RelatedIdentifer" property in Datacite, but may use different selections from the controlled lists in the subproperties. (See: [RelatedIdentifier in Datacite 4.4](https://support.datacite.org/docs/datacite-metadata-schema-v44-recommended-and-optional-properties#12a-relatedidentifiertype)) As is, Bess's example might use "Related Item" for a better fit to Datacite. (See: [Related Item property in Datacite 4.4](https://support.datacite.org/docs/datacite-metadata-schema-v44-recommended-and-optional-properties#20-relateditem)) 

**It will be important to check that both of these fields in Dublin Core/DataSpace have been used consistently, before assuming which of the aforementioned Datacite properties should be applied.**  

Additionally, we should discuss whether some Dublin Core properties have information that we don't want transferred to Datacite. These might contain information that isn't needed or desired in the new infrastructure. For example, I think Wind will have some thoughts on "Collection" for the main collection. However, these may be important to keep in place for PPPL. 

In Bess's example, "Description" is capturing an auto-generated message about the README that might not be useful -- but that's something we need to discuss. I'm finding inconsistencies with how "description" is used. For [this example of chemistry data](https://dataspace.princeton.edu/handle/88435/dsp01z890rx36m) the description property was used to provide info about the software used. For [another chemistry data example](https://dataspace.princeton.edu/handle/88435/dsp01s1784p89m), the "description" property is used to describe a supplementary source. In both cases, this does not map from Dublin Core "description" property to DataCite "description" property. Different properties would be used for this info in Datacite.
